title: Case Study: Hodgkin's Lymphoma with Cervical and Mediastinal Involvement
clinical_history: A 35-year-old male, previously healthy, presented with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss. He initially noticed a painless swelling in his left neck, which has gradually increased in size. Recently, he has experienced difficulty swallowing and occasional shortness of breath. Imaging studies revealed a large mediastinal mass and multiple cervical lymph nodes.

nprs.affected_area: constant, dull ache in the cervical region and upper chest
intermittent, sharp pain in the cervical region with movement

aggrevating_factors: prolonged sitting or standing, neck movement, swallowing
picture: 24-hour picture shows constant dull ache with intermittent exacerbations
past_history: tonsillectomy at age 10, no previous cancer diagnosis
medical_history: recent diagnosis of Hodgkin's Lymphoma, stage II
personal_history: married, two young children, works as an accountant
imaging: CT scan showing a large mediastinal mass and multiple cervical lymph nodes, PET scan showing increased uptake in the affected areas
